In this specific case, the time signature of 12/8 would lead to each measure being composed of two quarter notes. This is because in a 12/8 time signature there are twelve eights within one measure, where an eight note is represented by a dotted whole note or two half notes played in sequence (half + half = whole). Therefore since our list contains ten quarter notes, it must be divided into five measures of two quarter notes each. Each pair of quarter notes represent a single dotted whole note. The length of these measures will therefore be as follows:
[0.5] [0.5] [0.5] [0.5] [0.5].
The first measure begins at index zero (0), which corresponds with the start of our list. For example, we can see that the list begins with an eighth note followed immediately afterwards by a quarter note. Since the combination of an eighth plus a quarter note is equivalent to three quarters of a beat, the duration of the first quarter note will be 3 / 4 of a beat. The next element on the list is another eighth note, meaning that together they form a half note. Therefore the second quarter note takes up the remaining fourth of the beat. Similarly for all subsequent elements of the list. We calculate the duration of the second through fifth measures in exactly the same way.

In general, when determining how long any given note value lasts relative to other note values, you can use this rule of thumb:

- A sixteenth note equals four sixteenths.
- An eighth note equals two eighths.
- A quarter note equals one quarter, two eighths, or four sixteenths.
- A half note equals two halves, or four quarters.
- A whole note equals two wholes or four halves.

Since there are two beats per measure in a 2/2 time signature, each beat represents a quarter note duration. Therefore, the length of one measure would be equivalent to four quarter notes (since there are two beats and each beat is a quarter note long), and hence 14 measures would correspond to 56 quarter notes (i.e., 7 half notes x 4 = 28, which is the number of measures multiplied by their respective durations). In general, this method works for any time signature, since we simply need to count the number of quarter notes to determine how many measures there are, regardless of the actual length or rhythm of those measures.
